Hi Jeff,

On 20 avr. 2013, at 20:35, Jeff Clune wrote:
> However, my point =
is that you don't *always* need a quantitative test. I agree that there are=
 many papers that describe some very complex system, show some cool results=
, and we don't learn anything. But sometimes there are papers that show som=
ething extremely impressive and don't have any informative quantitative mea=
sures, and we learn a lot. It is the job of the reviewer to judge whether t=
here is a contribution: but a reviewer should not start with the assumption=
 that "if there is no quantitative test, it's not science and is not publis=
hable." My guess is that you agree with that, right?

I agree. What I was t=
rying to explain in the previous e-mail was: (1) we need to learn something=
 from the paper and (2) quantitative analysis is an easy way to argue somet=
hing in a convincing way.

I agree that the reviewer should not start with =
the assumption "if there is no quantitative test, it's not science and is n=
ot publishable.=94 However, I think that it is much harder to write a convi=
ncing paper without any quantitative test than with the help of measures/co=
mparisons/etc. As a result, as a reviewer, I start being suspicious when I =
see a paper without strong quantitative results. I may accept it, but I kno=
w that the challenge =97 for the author =97 will be more difficult.

Anothe=
r important point is that there is, in my opinion, a strong correlation bet=
ween weak papers and papers without strong quantitative results. Correlatio=
n does not imply causation, but we somehow learn to have an intuitive bad f=
eeling when we see a paper without quantitative results.

> Here is one str=
ong argument for not mandating a quantitative test: we have not created AI =
yet, so there are many things that humans can judge better than computers/q=
uantitative tests. Take computer vision, for example. All of us are blown a=
way by the images that resulted on Picbreeder,

[Picbreeder is not related =
at all with computer vision]


> Picbreeder taught us a lot about why CPPNs=
 are powerful and interesting, but they did not do so with numbers. My gues=
s is that the Picbreeder papers did jump through some hoops to provide numb=
ers to satisfy reviewers that insist on them (I forget at this point, it's =
been a while since I read those papers), but those numbers likely taught us=
 very little about the central advance. 

Agreed. Sometimes, examples can t=
each us many things. But, again, it=92s hard to make a strong points with e=
xamples. I=92m not saying it=92s impossible and your example is probably a =
good example. 

> The same is true for many domains: if I come up with a ne=
w story-telling algorithm, the judgement of whether it is a huge advance wo=
uld be you listening to the stories and thinking about whether they feel mo=
re natural and impressive than what came before.

This is typically quantif=
ied by taking 30 people and make them grade your story. My subjective opini=
on does not count that much.

> Do you agree?

I agree with you. Neverthele=
ss, our field is young and I think we have to put pressure to have strong p=
apers on which we can build strong foundations for future researches. One w=
ay to put this pressure is to have high standards and encourage to measure =
everything that is measurable/comparable, so that the average paper is as g=
ood as possible. Keep in mind that papers like =93look, cool simulated robo=
ts!" are making our field weaker.

Again, I=92m advocating that we should j=
udge papers by how much they teach us. I think we agree on this. Quantitati=
ve analysis is an easy way to teach something to the reader, other ways are=
 possible. But they are harder.

Best regards,
=97 JBM
